bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, March 3, 1950

div1.p: Truby sends Hench a letter from Lambert, and Truby's reply to Lambert. He says that Lambert is evidently beginning another drive to get on the Roll of Honor.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, March 3, 1950
div1.opener:
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO 18, CALIFORNIA
Mch, 3/50
Dear Dr Hench,
div1.p:
Sorry to bother you, but I think
that the inclosed letter from Gust Lambert with
my answer is important and that you
should have it in your files-

Notice that his letter was supposed to
come from Birmingham, Ala. but it was
post marked in Chicago. Evidently Lambert
is beginning another drive to get on the
Roll of Honor and now seems to have both
funds & some brains behind his efforts-
Notice his extensive trip through the south
including Cuba. Also note that parts of the
letter are somewhat garbled in the L. style,
because the person who prepared the letter could
not quite get the exact ideas L. wanted to
express- I am quite sure that men no
men were innoculated with infected mosquitoes
at the y. f. Hospital, as that would not have
ruined the value of the experiment. Mosquitoes
were probably placed on y. f. patients there in order
to infect the insects and then those mosquitoes
were taken to Camp Lazear where they were,
at the proper time, placed on the volunteers
who were there in quarantine waiting to be
given the test-

The first sentence of par 2 probably refers
Tr
to something Ames did after he left Cuba.
Gen Kean once told me that Ames had done
a criminal stunt of that kind at some
place in the South after Ames had left
Cuba. I do not know the details but Kean
thought it so bad that Ames should have
been prosecuted- Possibly you have heard
the same story from Kean.

You will remember that I wrote Lambert
that I would not discuss the y. f. episode
with him any further. That was in 1944.
So, when this letter came I was inclined
to ignore it. But after careful consideration
I decided that the best policy would be to
write him a firm, but courteous letter expressing
my views and conclusions. I have not
sent a copy to Gen. Kean for I do not want to
worry him as he may be very feeble- As
I think you & Kean have some sort of working
arrangement, probably with the S. S. O., to protect
the Roll of Honor from attacks of this kind, I
feel that you will know best what to do
with this matter-

We are all looking forward to seeing you
& Mrs Hench in June at the S. F. a. m. a. meeting
Hope you are fine and that you are
able to find a reasonable amount of time
for rest and recreation.
